awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a portable, affordable, multiline braille display powered by chemical fuels. In this increasingly digital society, computer screens serve as the primary interface for consuming and communicating information. Blind and visually impaired people cannot use computers by conventional means, instead using audio-based, screen reading software and refreshable braille displays to meet digital information needs. Braille displays, which are needed for precision reading and writing tasks (such as checking spelling and grammar) can only present a single line of information, usually 40 characters at a time. The display limitations of these devices are exacerbated by their staggering costs; Reliable displays are priced at $3,000 or more. Current actuation technologies cannot meet the need for multiline devices due to their high material and integration costs, and core technologies have remained essentially unchanged for decades.  Lowering the cost of a single-line display may increase accessibility for the blind, while an affordable multiline display may result in even greater impact. The goal for the proposed technology is to meet needs to both extend access to businesses and institutions that seek to provide refreshable braille to their own employees, customers, and visitors.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a multiline braille display powered by chemical fuels.  The proposed technology is based on a soft microfluidic system that distributes gaseous chemical fuels to microliter volume cylinders. Sparks ignite the gas in individual chambers resulting in the pulsed actuation of elastomeric membranes that cover the top of each cylinder. The core innovation enabling this functionality stems from the realization that the flames in each cylinder quench themselves at the microfluidic intake port. Thus, valves are not required to control individual actuations, previously unrealized in soft, pneumatic actuation arrays. Removing the need for valves simplifies the system architecture, reduces system size, and substantially lowers the system cost. The system level innovations in this project mayu resolve downstream technical challenges present in other tactile display technologies. An all-rubber composition allows for the design of a hermetically sealed platform which prevents dust and liquid ingress, and which may eliminate damage from impact. In addition, while maintenance is a large pain point for many braille display customers, the proposed display interface is inexpensive and may be completely replaced, as it contains small volumes of molded silicone rubber and wire.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Ronald Heisser led a project to develop a novel portable braille display, focusing on soft tactile actuators. This report outlines the journey from concept to testing, showcasing the technology’s innovative design and user feedback. Over 100 stakeholders, including blind individuals, educators, and assistive technology experts, were interviewed. Heisser also presented the technology at a major conference for the blind, gathering real-time feedback. The core of the project was a soft braille display utilizing elastomeric actuators driven by explosive pressure differentials, a potential game-changer for braille accessibility.

Heisser’s soft braille display offers a significant advancement in tactile technology. It uses a novel mechanism where domed membranes flip inward and outward through explosive pressure differentials, reducing mechanical parts to a single molded sheet, making it more durable. The display consists of a 10x10 grid of dots, each 2 mm wide and 1 mm tall, spaced 2.5 mm apart. These are made from silicone rubber, molded into a flexible actuation surface over a printed circuit board (PCB), all encapsulated in PDMS to ensure durability.

The actuation system relies on microfluidic conduits carrying fuel and exhaust gases, ignited to cause rapid dome eversion. Each dome flips in about 0.24 milliseconds, with a tip velocity of 8.3 meters per second, allowing up to 4,000 dot changes per second—well beyond what is needed for braille reading speeds.

Heisser engaged with over 100 stakeholders to ensure the device met user needs. These interviews highlighted common issues with existing braille devices, such as size, weight, and slow refresh rates. Users expressed a need for portable, durable displays that support multiline text and tactile graphics. The interviews, funded by the National Science Foundation’s I-Corps program, helped validate the technology and assess its market potential.

Through I-Corps, Heisser refined the braille display based on feedback. The program helped highlight areas for improvement, which were included in a paper submitted to Science. While users liked the display, some found the combustion power source limiting. However, for specific uses like teaching math and music, combustion may be acceptable since no alternatives exist for a portable, full-page refreshable braille display.

Heisser also showcased the device at a major conference for the blind, collecting positive feedback from live demonstrations. Attendees appreciated the clear, easy-to-read braille dots and the display’s lightweight design. The event facilitated networking with other researchers and opened doors for further development.

The soft braille display underwent rigorous testing, and most users reported a positive experience. They found the tactile dots easy to interpret, and the device’s soft material comfortable to touch. Its ability to display both text and tactile graphics was also highly appreciated. The device was durable and performed well under environmental stress, such as water exposure.

Users successfully read braille inscriptions and tactile graphics, meeting basic reading speed requirements. The device’s rapid dot actuation ensured smooth operation, further validated by user feedback.

The soft braille display shows great promise in enhancing braille literacy and accessibility. Its elastomeric bistability, combined with explosive pressure differentials, makes it a reliable and user-friendly device. The single-sheet construction reduces mechanical failures, offering an edge over existing displays. The testing phase confirmed that the device met braille reading speed and tactile accuracy benchmarks.

However, a key challenge is the need for a stored oxygen source to power combustion. While the design incorporates miniature regulators and solenoid valves for fuel and oxygen management, frequent oxygen replacement could limit practicality for some users. Future research should explore alternative fuel sources and optimize fuel management for better portability.

Stakeholder engagement provided valuable insights, with positive feedback indicating the technology’s potential to improve braille accessibility. The I-Corps program was critical in validating the device and identifying market needs. Despite the challenges of using combustion as a power source, it may still be viable for specific use cases such as math and music education, where alternatives for a portable, full-page refreshable braille display do not exist.

 


Last Modified: 10/16/2024
Modified by: Robert Shepherd

Image
  • Combustion powered soft tactile display
    Ronald Heisser
    Copyrighted
    Robert Shepherd
    Tactile Display
